title: Could any creditor place a lien on my patent without me knowing about it?
question: I have received a U.S. patent after filing Chapter 13. It did not generate any income while I have been paying off a 36 months plan, and I did it on time and got a discharge. It did not have any license or royalties. It had never made any money afterworlds including now.
answers:
A person who owns a vested security interest in a patent -- conveyed either by the patent owner or by law -- may perfect that interest via a UCC filing without informing the patent owner. As my colleagues note, the holder of the security interest may, and should, also record it with the Patent Office.

You may have a bigger problem, however.

Under the Bankruptcy Code not only is a patent "intellectual property" that must be disclosed on the filer's asset schedules but so is a patent application. 11 U.S.C. 101(35A). If you filed your patent application before filing your bankruptcy petition you were required to list the application on Schedule A/B [in fact, the current form has a dedicated line item for intellectual property]. Moreover, property acquired during the pendency of a Chapter 13 case generally becomes part of the bankruptcy estate -- and your patent [whether generating license revenue or not] is property.

You need to discuss all of this with your own California-licensed bankruptcy attorney. The consequences of failing to list an asset on a bankruptcy petition or failing to disclose property earned during a bankruptcy can be dire. Good luck.

Any lien on a patent would have to be registered with someone in order to be effective, whether it is a UCC lien or a lien at the USPTO. You can also search the bankruptcy records to ensure it was not sold or distributed during the bankruptcy. Chances are since patents require maintenance fees to uphold, the patent may already be in the public domain.

You would probably receive notice of the lien. You can check the US Patent Assignment records for your patent, any recorded liens would show up.
For more detailed advice, I recommend that you contact an experienced Copyright/IP attorney to advise you in confidence about your options and potential costs. Many IP specialty firms, like ours, offer an initial free conference by telephone, video conference or in person if you are available locally and would be happy to speak with you. Call and speak with an experienced Copyright/IP attorney who can assist you.

Yes, but it's likely that a creditor would have recorded any liens with the USPTO. You can check that by visiting:
http://portal.uspto.gov/pair/PublicPair
Select "Patent Number" and enter the patent number in the box. Click search, then click the on the "Assignments" tab. Any assignment documents, including liens, that have been filed with the USPTO should be listed.

Your state law may require a lienholder to notify you when they file the lien. Your state probably has a database you can search for liens, even if you weren't notified.
